div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Commencing October 1st the steamers are intended to leave Port Said every Monday at 5 p.m.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 October. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.p: The weather remains cool and fine with rather chilly nights. An easterly wind still prevails, and through the barometer is falling slightly there is little indication of any change.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1906.

div.head: MINISTRY OF EDUCATION.
div.p: The news of Saad Bey Zagloul's appointment as Minister of Public Instruction will be received with surprise, of that we are certain.but we are also confident that it will be a pleasant surprise to all parties In our opinion Saad Bey's appointment is a bold but liberal measure on the part of the Government. It will show that the authorities (pace some of their Nationalist critics) have the interests of education at heart. It will refute the allegation, so often repeated by Mustapha Kamel, that no Egyptian of independent judgment and progressive views can ever be appointed to the Cabinet under the "iron rule of the Occupation.' It will emphasise the readiness of the British Agency to support the genuinely progressive element among the Moslem natives of the country. It will gladden all who have the welfare of Egypt at heart, and if as we believe the departed souls of the just are conscious of what passes on earth, the spirit of Sheikh Mohamed Abdou will rejoice that the merits of one of his most noted disciples have been publicly recognised. It is our earnest hope that the new Minister of Public Instruction will meet with the success to which his abilities and courage alike entitle him.

div.head: HUNGARIAN INFLUENCES
div.p: Some time may elapse before the actual causes of Count Goluchowski's fall can be publicly stated, even if they are, authentically known. One thing can, however, says the 'Times be affirmed without fear of competent contradiction-—namely, that Count Goluchowski need not have resigned if he had cared to take hints thrown out by Hungarian statesmen. Even Dr. Wekerle presented no ultimatum, but left open several ways of escape. Count Goluchowski appears, however, to have disdained the em­ployment of small means to placate the largely unjustified resentment felt against him in Hungarian Coalition circles, and it is even probable that those Hungarians who have had most to do with the present crisis will presently attest that Count Goluchowski's conduct has been the conduct of a gentleman and a grand seigneur. Nevertheless, his fall will be welcomed in Hungary as the fulfilment of a desire that had almost become a national aspiration. The legend that he influenced the foreign Press against Hungary during the recent crisis is as unfounded as the le­gend concerning the existence of an anti- Magyar Court Camarilla in Vienna but legends persist in Hungary even after pro­minent Hungarians have perceived their baselessness. Yet Count Goluchowski has not been overthrown by the Hungarian Govern­ment in the same sense that his predecessor, Count Kalnoky, was overthrown by the Banffy Cabinet eleven and a-half years ago Then it was a direct trial of strength, and Hungary, as usual, proved the stronger. Now it has been rather the existence of an unpleasant atmosphere that induced the Foreign Minister to ask for pledges which the Hungarian Government could scarcely give, and to ignore saving suggestions which he deemed incompatible with his dignity. He rode for a fall and has fallen.

This is not the version current in certain ignoble journalistic effusions in Vienna and Buda­pest, but it is the more noteworthy in that it proceeds from well-informed quarters where Count Goluchowski has never been popular Doubtless other than Hungarian causes, con­tributed to persuade him to resign now rather than await the verdict of the Delegations although he was practically certain of seeing the Foreign Office estimates adopted by a large majority of his Hungarian and Austrian critics. The dispute with Servia has assumed an un­promising complexion, and it may be easier for another than Count Goluchowski to settle it without loss of prestige. The work of reform in Macedonia is not progressing satisfactorily, and a new statement on foreign affairs could hardly have had in November as confident a ring as it had even last June. Perhaps also Count Goluchowski no longer enjoyed the confidence of the Wilhelmstrasse to the same extent as for­merly. Some degree of ill-humour is said to have attended the publication of the Emperor William's flamboyant telegram of thanks for Austro-Hungarian help at Algeciras, though whether the ill-humour was due to the publica­tion or to the consequences of the publication it is difficult to ascertain. The attacks directed against Count Goluchowski on acount of the alleged unsatisfactory character of Austro Italian relations are wholly unjust and dis­ingenuous to boot.

Whatever its immediate causes, and however loud the satisfaction that his fall may evoke in Hungary and also in Austria,Count Goluchowski will retire with the feeling that he ha- been for nearly twelve years a faithful servant of his Imperial and Royal master, and a not untalented collaborator with him in maintain­ing peace in Europe. His departure will be sincerelv regretted by the Diplomatic Corps to which his good humour and easy, polished manner has endeared him. His successor may grapple with the difficulties and overcome the limitations of the position with greater success than Count Goluchowski but will hardly fill it with more tact or reap a greater measure of personal esteem.

div.head: CAPITALIST
div.p: wanted with £12.000 for Cigarette Factory, exporting approximately 12 millions of cigarettes a year. Yearly revenue probably 20 percent as per last balance. Please address letters F.D.S. c/o "Egyptian Gazette" offices.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: To-day's plague bulletin reports the admission to hospital of an Armenian of the Menshieb quarter.

div.head: Chrysanthemum Show.
div.p: The Alexandria Horticultural Society will hold their annual Chrysanthemum Show at San Stefano on Saturday next.

div.head: Land and Mortgage Co.
div.p: The numbers are announced of 44 Four and a Half per cent. Debentures, amounting to £ 1,4' 0, which have been drawn for paymen at par on Nov. 12.

div.head: The Legislative Council.
div.p: It is reported that two new permanent numbers will be appointed shortly to succeed the late Mohamed Abdon and Abdel Khalik el Saadat on the Legislative Council.

div.head: The Rise in Land.
div.p: Cairo building land has risen a further 50 % in price, reports the "Mokattam." This is due to the growing population and the inadequate accommodation therefor.

div.head: The Cotton Harvest.
div.p: At a harvest thanksgiving service at a church in Blackburn, Lancashire, recently, the vicar mindful of the staple trade of the district, made it a celebration of the cotton harvest, and cotton pods, etc. were used for the decoration of the church.

div.head: Arrest of a Thief.
div.p: The police of Zigszig. acting on telegraphic instructions from Suez, have arrested a European who had fled thither with two Credit Foncier Egyptien shares, which he had stolen from a comrade of his at Suez. He is now under arrest, thanks to the prompt action of Saghcolaghassi De Turris, moawin of police of Suez.

div.head: The Shoubra Crime.
div.p: A further enquiry into this now mysterious affair has been ordered by M. de Reffye, in consequence of revelations which tend to inculpate the bowabs of the Maison Ciccolani. Peillard father and son have been acquitted, though facts and circumstances were strongly against at least the son.

div.head: Suez Canal.
div.p: On the 26th October, 12 vessels, of which 8 were northward and 4 southward bound, transited the canal, and paid for transit and passenger toll Fr. 361,238.92. Of these 7 were British, 1 German, 2 Danish, 1 Italian, and 1 Spanish. The total receipts since October 27 are Fr. 7,034,993.40 and during that time 271 vessels transited the Canal, 126 being northward, and 145 southward bound.

div.head: A Domestic Tragedy.
div.p: A young native living at Bab Sidra, Alexandria, who had been divorced from his wife and whose attempts at resuming conjugal relations met with a non-possumus attitude from his spouse, clinched matters yesterday by stabbing her several times. The woman fell unconscious, but was not mortally wounded. Seeing his wife fall, however, the man imagined he had killed her and, filled with remorse, he drew a revolver and shot himself dead.

div.head: The Cairo Season.
div.p: Mena House Hotel will open for the season, under the management of Mr. A. Klinger, of the Nungovich Hotels Company,on November 1, remaining open for six months. The National Hotel opens on the same date, aud Mr. Bauer looks forward to having an excellent season. He has already received a large number of applications for rooms. The new dining room has now been quite completed, and looks very handsome. The Grand Hotel, Helouan, will also open on November 1.

div.head: Sequel to Fashn Tragedy.
div.p: Abdel Kader el Saadi, son of Lamloum Bey, head of the Fawaid tribe of Arabs,was acquitted last Saturday by the Native Court of Beni Souef of the charge of murdering two women. As a demonstration of delight at the termination of the case in his son's favor, Lamloum Bey encouraged his tribesmen to fire blank cartridges into the air. One gun, however, was charged with shot by mistake and,being let off accidentally, fatally wounded one man and inflicted serious injuries on two others.

div.head: Shop Breaking at Port Said.
div.p: At Port Said, on Friday night, two men were surprised in the act of breaking into a ship chandler's in the Roe Hamdi. They then tried to make off with a barrow that was in the street outside, but wore prevented by the watchmen on the premises, whom they thereupon attacked with cudgels. The police appeared at this juncture, and managed to arrest one of the outlaws, who is a European. One of the watchmen was seriously wounded, and taken to hospital. The store was owned by a Mr. L. Feilla.

div.head: Hotel Robbery.
div.p: Singularly awkward was the the predication in which a railway clerk, Raphael Effendi, and a cook, Hussein Aly, were placed when on the morrow of their arrival at the Hotel de France, Port Said, they woke to find their clothes and valuables had surreptitionsly disappeared from their bedrooms. The thief was also missing ; his name was not entered in the registry, and a process-verbal has been made out against the manager for this negligence. The fugitive is a native of Zagaz an evil character who had just concluded several months incarceration. The police are hot in pursuit of him.

div.head: EGYPTIAN NATIONALISM
FRENCH SUPPORT IMPOSSIBLE.
div.p: The "Temps" publishes an article on Egypt- ian Nationalism. The Nationalists repudiated the ulterior design of reestablishing the rule of Turkey. Politically, they wish for the end of the English Occupation; morally, they would hasten the civilising evolution of Islam. Upon the first point the support of France is impossible; upon the second the Egyptian Press will recognise the Liberal tendencies of France concerning Mahomedanism in Algeria, Tunis, and the Sudan. (Havas)

div.head: BELGIAN DIPLOMATIC AGENCY.
div.p: M. MASKENS TRANSFERRED.
A Havas telegram from Brussels announces that M. Maskens, Belgian Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General, has been appointed Belgian Minister at Athens. He will be succeeded in Cairo by M. le Gaissier.

div.head: PRINCE GEORGE'S CRUISE
div.p: Suez, Saturday.
The Danish steamer Burma, having on board H.R.H. Prince George of Greece and the Danish Princes, sailed from Suez early this morning en route to the Far East.
During the ship's short stay at Suez, she was dressed with flags.

div.head: PRINCES NARROW ESCAPE.
div.p: Prince Mahmoud Pasha Hamdi, uncle of the Khedive, had a narrow escape while crossing the Upper Egypt railway line at Ghizah, on the Pyramids road, on Wednesday. By some oversight, the barrier was raised and several carriages had already crossed, when a goods train, northward bound, came up at full speed. Pascal Defranco, the chauffeur of the Prince, had sufficient presence of wind to draw up, and so avoided an accident, the result of which might have been no less fearful than that which befell the Prince's cousin, Prince Ibrahim.
Maitre Carton de Wiart, motoring from Abbassieb, also had a close shave ; his motor passed within a few inches of the buffers of a locomotive.

div.head: THE RECENT STORM.
div.p: The recent storm which passed over Egypt travelled from the West, visiting Malta, where on Friday week the lightning and thunder wore fearful. One church steeple was struck and injured, and several houses were damaged considerably. The bastions were struck in several places, and two policemen were dashed to the ground and stunned. There was no loss of human life. It was reported that 3 1/4 inches of rain fell during the night.

div.head: LOCAL WEDDING.
div.p: On Saturday, at the British Consulate, Alex­andria, before Mr. E. B. Gould, I S.O., Consul General, the civil marriage of Mr. Ernest Pittuk, Suez and Mies Gladys Williams took place, tbs contract being signed and witnessed by the bride's brothers, Mr. R. S. and Mr. R. T. Williams. The party afterwards pro­ceeded to St. Mark's Church, where the reli­gious ceremony took place, Rev. Longley officiating. In the church a good many mem­bers of the British community witnessed the interesting ceremony, after which the happy pair started through a shower of rose leaves and the blessings of their friends on their way to Cairo for their honeymoon.

div.head: EGYPTIANS IN AMERICA.
div.p: A Cincinnati contemporary says Seven young Egyptians arrived in Cincinnati yesterday to attend the Medical Department of the University of Cincinnati. They say that the . fame of the medical colleges in the Queen City is known the world over, and that they made the long journey from Cairo to attend here. They speak English freely, having studied it in the University of Cairo, but would not attend the medical university there because it is under Mohamedan rule. The strangers will return to Egypt as soon as they complete their studies here.

Another paper states:— Claiming that io their home country it is a sign of respect to wear the red fez they use for hats, seven Egyptians attending the medical department of the University of Cincinnati were surprised at a request to remove their caps in a local
restaurant.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Messageries Maritimes mail-boat Portugal through the Straits of Messina at
noon on Saturday, and is due at Alexandria tomorrow morning.
The Ellerman S.S. Arabian sailed from Malta on Saturday evening, and is due here on Wednesday with a general cargo.

div.head: MINISTRY OF EDUCATION
NEW MINISTER APPOINTED
div.p: Great surprise and interest will be excited, especially in native circles, by the news of the appointment of Saad Bey Zaghloul, judge of the Native Court of Appeal, to the posi­tion of Minuter of Public Instruction, vice Hussein Pasha Fakhry, who retains the port­folio of the Ministry of Public Works.

The new Minister is of Egyptian origin, with a trace of Bedouin blood, a National­ist of the type of the late Sheikh Mohamed Abdo", and an efficient, honest, and energetic judge. His conduct at the Bar and on the Bench have won general respect for his abilities and admiration of his fairness and courage. A progressive and a patriot, firmly convinced that Egypt can only become a self-governing country when the Egyptians are morally and intellectually trained up to the European standard, he has had to bear much criticism from the conservative and Pan-Islamic elements, and even from Europeans, who considered him an unpractical idealist (a notion, by the way, which his legal success should have dispelled). His private life and his intellec­tual attainments alike fit him to bear the responsibilities of this new office with high credit.
Saad Bey Zaghloul was summoned by the Khedive on Saturday evening and came down to Alexandria yesterday, being granted a private audience by his Highness at Montazah Palace.

div.head: EGYPT AND ITALY.
div.p: SAVINGS BANK FACILITIES.

An agreement has been concluded between the Italian and Egyptian postal authorities whereby, on and after November 1, sums deposited in the Egyptian and Italian postal savings banks may be transferred from one country to the other. This will no doubt prove an immense boon to the very large number of Italian depositors in the local savings banks, who are continually remitting money to their native land.

div.head: WALKER AND MEIMARACHI.
div.p: Half of the land belonging to Walker and Meimarachi, Limited, between the French Agency and the company's new buildings, has just been sold at a profitable price. The area of the land sold is 2,469 square metres. The land was originally purchased by Mr. Con­stantine Meimarachi, the managing director, from the Egyptian Estates at £15 per metre, and he passed it over to the company at the same price. Owing to this action of Mr. Meimarachi, the profit to the company now is about £26 per metre,which gives a total profit to the company of about £26,000 over this deal alone, leaving aside the other half of the land on which the company's new building is. Mr. Meimarachi is to be congratulated on his foresight, as the profit of this transaction is solely due to him.

div.head: THE NOUVEAUTES INCIDENT
ACCUSED SENT TO PRISON-
div.p: On Saturday Messrs. G — and L------------------
appeared (as stated in our issue of the 27th inst.)on a change of drunkenness and disorder­ly conduct, aggravated by assault on Eurico Pollino, au employe of the Nouveautes Theatre, Cairo.

The case opened with the evidence of M. Cesare Lauri, proprietor and impresario of the Nouveautes Theatre. He stated that defendants were in a box at his theatre on the night of the 21st inst. Two other young men were with them. One of the defendants sat with his legs hanging over the side of the box, and caused some annoyance by dropping his cigarette ash on the public. Witness saw this, and sent an employe to request them to keep quiet. Defendants were inclined to be noisy. He could not say whether they were drunk or not.
Mr L------ seized the employe and turned him
out of the box.
On receiving a communication from the employe, witness went to the box and asked one of the defendants to sit properly in the box. Defendant, whom he believed to be Mr.
G------ , told him to go away and made signs
of a hostile nature. He then rose and struck at him. Witness drew back and the blow fell very lightly on his cheek under the right eye.

A policeman arrived and went to the box, where one of the party (not in Court) said "ana bimbashi warif shugli, etla" ("I am a bimbashi and know my business—be off!") The police­man withdrew. As the performance had stopped Witness addressed the soi-disant bimbashi, asking him to get the party away. The public were much excited, and rushed up to the box. Defendants resisted and there was a scuffle on the stair case, where one of the defendants tried to attack witness. At fast two European and six or seven native police came up and the defendants, after a struggle, were taken to the caracol to make his complaint. Defendants bad not arrived. Shortly afterwards he hearda cab come up and loud shouts by the police.
On cross-examination, witness denied that choruses were ever sang by the public at his theatre. They might be at the Alcazar and other music halls.
M. Petrarchi complained to him, as did a lady in a box next to defendants, of their misbehaviour.

Other witnesses, among them M. Michel Salman, interpreter to the Italian Consulate, and the waiter Pollino, gave corroborative evidence. They asserted that defendants threw chairs and offered a vigorous resistance, "like lions," to the police and public.

Counsel for the defence asked for an adjourn­ment to enable evidence to be called for the defence, and the case was finally adjourned till this morning, the defendents being allowed to find bail in two sareties of £50 each on also giving their own recognisances.
SENTENCE DELIVERED.
At the time of going to press we received a telegram from our Cairo Correspondent report­ing that the defendants have been sentenced to fourteen days' imprisonment without the option of a fine.
THE LOTTERY CASE.

This morning, judgment was given by the Misdemeanour Court of the Alexandria Mixed Tribunals in the case brought by the Ministere Public against M. Melides, agent of the Credit Foncier Hollandais, and the "Phare d'Alexandrie."

The case has aroused great interest locally, as the question at issue was the right of Egyptian newspapers to publish the adver­tisements of foreign lotteries despite the recent Lottery Law enacted by the Egyptian Government. The publication of lottery advertisements has hitherto been a lucrative and legitimate source of revenue to the 1 cal Press', and this was a test case to decide the efficacy of the new law as regards foreign lot­teries.

The Court decided against the "Phare d'Alexandrie" and M. Melides, ordering the former to desist from publishing the advertisements and the latter from selling the tickets of the Credit Foncier Hollandais.
MALTESE VICTORIA SHCOOL.

This excellent educational institution at Alexandria is making such great progress since Professor Caruana Nani has been headmaster that the Committee have met with a difficult problem. Students are flocking to the school in such numbers that application for admission have had to be refused, as no space is available and farther funds are needed. On the proposition of Mr. Leander Camilleri, the chairman of the committee, seconded by Mr. Albert Combo, the auditor, a pigeon shooting meeting is to be organised for this day week, the 3rd proxo. at the Rond Point Shooting Club, which has been graciously placed at the disposal of the com­mittee for this occasion by Messrs. Milani and Pereira. It is to be hoped that the a substantial addition to the School's fund. Some excellent sport is promised for next Saturday afternoon. At present the School accommodates 140 pupils, many of them being workmen, who come to the School in the evening after their hours of labour in order to be instructed in English, etc The School deserves the support not only of the members of the Maltese Colony in Alexandria, but throughout Egypt, as the centre of the Maltese Colony in Egypt is at Alexandria and the School in doing splendid work in instructing the poorer members of that Community.

div.head: ENGLISH OPERA IN CAIRO.
"THE SPRING CHICKEN."
div.p: "The Spring Chicken," which was given by the Bandmann Company on Saturday night, was a welcome change after the last three rather dull performances. The actors showed the influence of this lively piece, and confirmed the opinion we had formed from "The Run­away Girl."

Miss Corlass was even more charming than usual, especially in her peasant's dress in the first act. The dance in sabots to her song "I came to Paris for a change" was a great success. Mr. Harry Cole's disguises were one and all splendid : as father-in-law, expounding the wisdom of the man over 40 to Mr. Attwell (Maitre Babori) he was admirable; as the statue of Ajax, be was majestic ; as Zaza, most coy and attractive. Miss Leslie's song of the swallow was quite pretty. Mr. Attwell, Mr. Smith, his clerk, and Miss Hunter, as Mrs. Girdle, were all amusing. The only pity was that the chorus was too small, and their voices were lost at times. We cannot pass over the two Girdle children, Missus Vincent and Probyn, or Mr. Arthur, the waiter. Indeed all the performers deserve much credit, and the piece in itself is quite amusing.

div.head: AN ALEXANDRIAN GHOST STORY
div.p: Captain Gambier, in his "Links of My Life on Land and Sea" recently published by Mr. Fisher Unwin, relates a weird experience he encountered while in Egypt.

Captain Gambier was invited to stay in Alexandria with an old shipmate, Dr. Edwardes, who had been assistant surgeon on the Retribu­tion, but was now in practice in Alexandria. When, however, the Captain reached Edwardes's house he found he would have to dine and sleep there alone, as the doctor had been sum­moned to see a patient at some distance from Alexandria. Some time after the Captain bad retired to bed he woke "and distinctly saw a tall woman standing in the middle of the room. Thinking, naturally, that someone had mistaken the apartment, I put up my eyeglass and saw here features plainly, and the small curls on her forehead. She was dressed in a long shiny black dress, out square, with a broad lace collar hanging over the breast I was particularly struck with the deadly pallor of her face and the vacant look of her eyes, which seemed turned to me, and yet not see me. There appeared to be nothing uncanny about her, except the supernatural silence which surrounded her ; the room was so still that I might have heard her breathe. I watched her for over a minute, and then I moved to get op, when she tamed and walked towards a large press in the wall,* which I had not before noticed, and vanished. The impression of the bodily presence of someone was so strong that I jumped out of bed, went across the room—thinking the cupboard might lead into another—and opened the door through which I thought the woman had passed. The moon, as bright as day, streamed into the cupboard, and there facing me was a long black dress, with a broad lace collar, hang­ing on a peg. I was simply amazed. I pushed the dress aside, but there was nothing behind it"

"Wondering who the owner of this long black dress and lace collar might be," goes on the Captain, "doubtless some friend of Edwardes's, I went to bed again, absolutely persuaded that some living being bad been in the room and had got away somehow, and I was soon asleep. In the morning I met Edwardes at breakfast, and we had much talk of old days, but I purposely refrained from any allusion to what had passed in the night.

I soon learnt from him, however, that he had been married, and he incidentally mentioned that bis wife had died recently, and in the room now occupied by myself. I still held my peace, for I thought it would distress him whatever might be his point of view. These being almost pre photographic days, there was no portrait for me to see, so I had no confirmation of her identity with the im­pression of the night beyond that he said that his wife had been tall with dark curls."

div.head: THE SPHINX AS A STAGE EFFECT.
div.p: An attractive innovation is to be introduced by Mr. Tree in his production of "Antony and Cleopatra," which will take place at His Majesty's Theatre towards the end of December.

As the greater part of the play is laid in Egypt, Mr. Tree proposes to make the inscrutable figure of the Sphinx, gazing across the desert, indifferent to human suffering and affairs, the opening note of the play.

The giant figure in the sands will be the first picture in the production, and as it fades away the play begins. So, too, when Antony and Cleopatra, their passion ending in tragedy, have passed away and all is over, this emblem of eternity will appear again, only to fade again as the curtain falls.

For the painting of this great picture of the Sphinx Mr. Tree has commissioned Mr. Joseph Harker, the well-known scenic artist. Among these specially engaged to support Mr. Tree and Miss Constance Collier in the title roles are Mr. Norman Forbes and Mr. Julian L'Estrange.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Hussein Pasha Kamel is to be asked to accept the post of president of the National University Committee.

Lady Valda Machell is making an excellent recovery from her recent illness, but is still staying at St. James Palace, where she is occupying the apartments tenanted by her mother, Princess Victor of Hohenlohe, in En­gine-court. As soon as she is strong enough to bear the fatigue of the journey Lady Valda intends to return to Egypt, and hopes to rejoin her husband, Mr. Machell, in Cairo before very long. Her brother, Lieut. Col. Count Gleichen, C.V.D.,C.B., formerly director the Sudan Intelligence Department and now extra equerry to the King and military attache at Washington and Mexico, has keen promoted Colonel by brevet.
Lord Kitchener has been suffering from fever for the past fortnight He has left Simla for Umballa for change of air, acting on medical advice. There is no cause for alarm.
Coles Pasha resumed his duties on Saturday after bis return from leave, and yesterday morning he paid visits to Mustapha Pasha Fehmy and Mr. P. W. Machell.
Very Rev. Dean and Mrs. Butcher have returned to Cairo, and are at Church House.
Ahmed Mohsen Bey has returned to Alex­andria after a most enjoyable holiday in the Lebanon, where he has spent three months with his family, who return in a week or two.

Sir Hugh and Lady Smiley have returned to Claridge's after a visit to Captain Smiley's new country residence at Uckfield. They will leave in a few days for Belfast to pay visits before proceeding to Egypt for the winter.
Major R S. Oxley, 1st Battalion King's Rifle Corps, is leaving Cairo for Khartoum on Wednesday.

The following officers of the Coldstream Guards have recieved a month's leave of absence, with permission to travel in the Sudan and Blue Nile district: Capt. G. Lane, and Lieutenants J. C. Gibbs and W. M. Beckwith.

A marriage has been arranged, and will shortly take place, between Norton Bey, locomotive-carriage district superintendent, State Railways, Suez, and Fanny Maria, only child of the late Mr. Silvester Lomax, architect, Bolton.
Dr. and Mrs. Wakeling are returning by the P. and O. steamer Caledonia, and will arrive at Mena House on the 1st prox.

Among the passengers who arrived at Alex­andria this morning by the Austrian Lloyd S.S. Cleopatra were Count Kozebrodsky, the Austro-Hungarian Diplomatic Agent and Consul General, Chakour Pasha, Chakour Bey, Baron and Baroness von Trauttenberg, Mr. C. Salinas, Judge and Mrs. Montan, Mr. Blattner, Mr. Rolo, Mr. Cattaui, Mrs. Gottschlich, Mr. Cornish, Mr. Colucci, etc. Cav. Valle Bey and family, Mr. E. Suares, Mr. Max Stross Mr. Vivian Vernon, M. Manusardi, and Mr. Joseph Green returned from Europe by the S.S. Perseo yesterday. Herr von Moh1, Mr. Tamvaco and son, Mr. C. Giglio, and Mr. E. Siemen were among the passengers who sailed for Europe by the Austrian packet on Saturday. The Khedive has conferred the grade of Sanieh on Ali Bey Sarwar, formerly head­master of the Mansourah Industrial School. Mr. A. van Millingen, proprietor of the Windsor Hotel, returned to Alexandria from Constantinople this morning.

div.head:
ANARCHY IN MOROCCO.
FRENCH CRUISER DESPATCHED.

div.p: The shore end of the French cable has been cut off by tribesmen a few miles from here.
(Peuter)
Anarchy reigns in Morocco. The cruiser Jeanne d'Arc is leaving for Tangier. (Havas)

In consequence of the captureof an English* man and a Spaniard at Arzila, France and Spain are exercising the policing rights which were conferred on them at the Algeciras Con­ference, and have each despatched a warship. Meanwhile, the notorious El Raisuli has occupied Arzila on behalf of the Moorish Government, and restored order. (Peuter)
The French Government has instructed the military authorities to be ready to resist any aggressive action. (Reuter)

div.head:
MOORISH FINANCIAL NEEDS.
LOAN FROM GERMANY.

div.p: The German Minister has negotiated a small loan in order to relieve the Moorish Government's pressing needs. (Rater)

div.head:
RUSSIAN BOMB OUTRAGE.
CUSTOMS MONEY STOLEN.

div.p: Two bombs were thrown in the heart of the City to day at a van conveying Customs money to the treasury. One of the bomb throwers was killed and another wounded; a third was arrested. Two gendarmes escorting the van and a number of by standers were wounded.
(Later). The bomb-throwers succeeded in securing £38,600 with which they escaped. Six more have been arrested by soldiers. (Reuter)

div.head:
NEWFOUNDLAND FI8HING RIGHTS
AMERICANS REFUSE TO CONFORM.

div.p: American fishermen newly arriving off New­foundland refuse to conform with the compact of 23rd October, and renewed trouble is expected. The captain of His Majesty's cruiser Brilliant and the American commissioner are trying to arrange a compromise. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE SUBMARINE LUTIN.
RAISED AND OPENED.

div.p: The Lutin has been towed into the harbour of Sidi Abdallah. (Reuter)
The Latin has been refloated. (Havas)
The Latin has been raised and opened. The crew apparently died at their posts. Deaths were certified to have taken place at midday on the 16th instant. (Reuter)
It has been found that the Latin made water in six places. (Havas)
The Russian Foreign Minister, M. Iswolsky, now in Paris, will be received in special audience by the Emperor to morrow, and will have a conference with Prince von Bulow on
It is stated in Devonport that Vice-Admiral Sir Charles Drury will succeed Lord Charles Beresford in the command of the Mediterranean Fleet • (Reuter)
Football. The South Africans have played and won 10 matches and scored 240 points.
Rugby. The South Africans beat Newport by 8 points to nil.(Peuter)

div.head: BY MR. VERSCHOYLE.
div.p: As regards necessity for irrigation, countries may be divided into three classes—viz., countries in which irrigation is a sine qua non, and in which it is impossible to obtain any crop without it; countries in which, while not an absolute necessity, it is still a valuable asset, and commercially successful, owing to the increased yield of crops obtained by its aid, and the fact that it renders possible the cultivation of more valuable crops. Such countries have generally a fairly well distributed rainfall of about twenty-five inches per annum, or a badly distributed unseasonable rainfall of doable that amount or more, as is the case in Southern India. The third class comprise countries with a well-distributed rainfall of thirty inches and upwards, where irrigation systems, though often welcome in times of exceptional drought, would not be commercially successful. Egypt proper, or the Nile Valley from Assouan to Cairo and the Delta, is included in the first of these classes. Between Assouan and Cairo, and over two-thirds of the Delta, the rainfall nowhere exceeds three inches. Along the Mediterranean coast the fall is somewhat heavier, and reaches a mean of eight inches at Alexandria, which practically all occurs between the middle of November and middle of March. The necessity for irrigation having thus been demonstrated, the source of the water supply, the gracious river Nile, calls for a few words of description.

div.head: The Nile
div.p: The Nile rises south of Lake Victoria,. and drains a tract of 300,000 square kilometres. The mean annual rainfall over its basin varies from sixty to ten inches. The river bears the following names in its different reaches: - Between Lakes Victoria and Albert, the Albert Nile; between Lakes Albert and No, the Bahrel-Gebel ; between Lake No and Khartoum, the White Nile. The Nile proper commences at Khartoum. The main tributaries are the Saubat at kilometre 1,688 from Lake Victoria ; the Blue Nile at Khartoum (kilometre 2,526) ; the Atbara at kilometre 2,846. North of the Atbara junction, no tributary occurs. The total distance from Lake Victoria to the head of the Delta is 5,276 kilometres At the head of the Delta, the river bifurcates into the Rosetta and Damietta branches, each 230 kilometres in length.

The Saubat, Blue Nile, and Atbara contribute nearly the whole of the flood discharge ; the White Nile nearly the whole of the summer discharge. The moan maximum flood discharge reaching Assouan is 7,000 cubic metres per second, and the mean minimum summer discharge 410 cubic metres per second.

For the last 586 kilometres of its course the Bahr-el-Gebel traverses mighty swamps of undetermined area. So great is the regulat­ing effect of these swamps that only from forty to fifty per cent, of the summer and twenty to forty per cent of the flood discharge of the river reaches the White Nile. To capture this summer discharge without interfering with the existing flood regime, is the problem now being studied. Let us now see how the available supply is utilised.

div.head: Basin Irrigation
div.p: The systems of irrigation practised are the basin and perennial systems. Under the first, the laud receives one annual flooding ; under the second, waterings proceed uninterruptedly throughout the year. Basic irrigation has been in existence some 5,000 years, and formerly was universal. In 1820 perennial irrigation replaced the Delta basins, and in 1875 reached Middle Egypt Since 1901 the conversion of basins into perennial tracts has been pushed vigorously, and in three years' time only 950,000 acres of basins will be left in Egypt.

The basins are enclosed by the river banks, banks paralleling them, and cross-banks reaching the desert Basins vary from a few hundred to fifty thousand acres in area. Where the desert does not break the chain of basins by impinging on the river, water is passed for­ward from one system to another when necessary. The basin canals begin to draw water about the middle of August, and the irrigation is completed, and the basins laid dry, about November 30. As the water recedes the winter crops of wheat, barley, beans, clover, lentils, and vetches, are sown broadcast. In 1900 there were 3,350 kilometres of basin canal and 2,900 kilometres of basin banks.

On the berms of the river, 297,000 acres in area, on temporary wells in the basins, and plots isolated from the latter by banks, are grown summer crops of sugar-cane, cotton, melons and millet, ard a flood crop of millet. These are irrigated by steam pumps on the river, and thousands of shadoofs on the river, canals, and wells. About twenty-five per cent. of the total basin tract yields a doable crop. The mean gross value of the crops to day is about L.E. 7. 7 per acre and the net value L.E. 5.5.

div.head: Perennial Irrigation
div.p: The area under perennial irrigation to day is 4,000,000 acres, and the kilometrage of perennial canals 11,574. The entire perennial tract in Middle Egypt is supplied by the Ibrahimieh Cana', 242 kilometres long. This, canal takes off at Assiout, and has a bed width of fifty metres, a summer depth of 4'0 metres and a flood depth of 8'0 metres, The discharge varies from 155 to 700 cubic metres per second.

The Delta is supplied by six main canals taking off between Cairo and the Delta barrage. The aggregate discharge of these canals is between 400 and 500 colic metres per second in summer, and 1 000 cubic metres per second in flood. A number of minor canals also draw direct from the river in flood. In Middle Egypt conditions render irrigation by gravitation generally possible. In the Delta conditions are

different, and two thirds of the summer irrigation is effected by lift. There are 4,000 steam pumps at work, and many thousand sakiehs and tabuts, primitive machines worked by oxen. In a tabut the chain of earthern pots is replaced by peripheral chambers on the wheel. Thousands of Archmedian screws, worked by hand, are also in use for small lifts.
The area of crops in the Delta in 1905 was

4.685,000 acres. The cultivated area was 3,157,000 acres, which means that forty eight percent of the latter gave a double crop. The gross value of the crop per acre of cultivation was about £E15.47, and the net value £E10.12.

div.head: Drainage
div.p: It is an accepted axiom that irrigation and drainage works must proceed simultaneously. Since 1883 much has been done to remedy past neglect of drainage in Egypt. There are to-day 1,813 kilometres of drains in Middle Egypt. and 3,400 kilometres in the Delta. The main drains in Middle Egypt discharge into the river. The Fayoum province drains into Lake Karun, 40 metres below sea level, and is there evaporated. Half of the western province of the Delta drains into Lake Mareotis, 3 metres below sea level, and is lifted into the sea by gigantio pomps. The remainder of the Delta drains into Lakes Edfu, Borillos and Menzaleh, all of which communicate with the sea. The drains have bed-widths at their outfalls of from 8 to 40 metre', and oarry from 2 to 2.5 meters of water. (' The Graphic?*)

div.head: NILE TRIPS FOR RESIDENTS.
div.p: Messrs. Thos. Cook and Sons (Egypt). Ltd. inform ns that at the commencement of the season they will make special redactions for residents in this country who desire this season to moke the Nile trip. Instead of the foil fare of £50, residents will be charged £25 for the sailings of November 13 and 27 and Deoember 4 from Cairo to Assouan, and £15 instead of £'22 for the express services of November 2, 9,16, and 23 and December 3 and 7. The return journey to Assouan takes 20 days and doubtless many residents who have spent the summer in Egypt will take advantage of the excellent terms, which include sight seeing. The express steamers take 19 days for the return journey, bat four of these are spout at an Assouan hotel and three days at Luxor.

div.head: POSSIBILITIES OF THE SUDAN.
div.p: On Tuesday week, Mr. Henry M'Neil, of Manchester, addressed the Bradford Chamber of Commerce on behalf of the British Cotton Growing Association. He said Bradford was the first place they had come to outside Lancashire for fands, because next to Lanca­shire, Bradford was the most interested in ootton. Mr. John Waugh, of Bradford, said from personal observations in the Sudan be was convinced that the Association was missing great opportunities in that area. He was oon- vinoed there was no finer investment in the world than cotton-growing in the Sudan. There was suitable land, and people expert at producing cotton* for the market

div.head: VANDALISM IN SINAI.
div.p: To the Editor op the "Egyptian Gazette." Sir,—I noticed in your review on Friday of

Professor Flinders Petrie's work on his recent archaeological explorations in the Sinaitic Peninsula that mention is made therein of the acts of vandalism committed by the English company, which up to lately had the concession for mining there. I am in a position to state that neither Messrs. Bewick, Moreing & Company, the concessionnaires,nor any of their employes were guilty of injuring the remains of antiquity within the area of their concession.

I was manager for some time of the concession, and when we came there we found that the inscriptions had been greatly damaged, evidently by Arab vandals in their search for turquoise. Strict orders were given by the company that all antiquities should be religiously preserved and, if any were found, should be handed over to the Egyptian Government —I am, etc.,
R. S. Milward. Alexandria, 27th October.

div.head: SATURDAY'S SKYE MEETING.
div.p: Saturday's Skye Meeting—the last racing meeting of the season—was held under ideal weather conditions. There was a somewhat disappointing attendance, considering the number of people who have returned from Europe, bat the afternoon proved a most enjoyable one. There were only five races on the card, and none of them were particularly exoiting, most of the favourites justifying the opinion of thsir baokers. Pilules du Docteur DEHAUT de Paris

n'hésitent pas à se purger, quand elles en ont besoin. Elles ne craignent ni le dégoût ni la fatigue, parce que, à l'opposé des autres purgatifs, celui-ci n'opère bien que lorsqu'il est pris avec de bons aliments et des boissons fortifiantes, telles que vin, café, thé. Chacun choisit, pour se purger, l'heure et le repas qui lui conviennent le mieux, selon ses occupations. La fatigue de la purgation étant annulée par l'effet de la bonne alimentation, on se décide aisément à recommencer autant de fois que cela est nécessaire.
